title: LAYING DOWN YOUR LIFE FOR THE SHEEP Part 3
scripture_text:
I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for
the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the
sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs
away.Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs away
because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. "I am the
good shepherd; know my sheep and my sheep know me---just as the Father
knows me and I know the Father---and I lay down my life for the sheep.
have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them
also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and
one shepherd The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my
life---only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay
it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority
to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.
devotional:
To 'lay down' your life is to live as a sacrifice so you can
spontaneously minister unto the needs of others.

To lay down your life is to cultivate a mindset that refuses to allow
your life to function on the basis of selfishness.

Laying down your life is more about character than heroism; it is more
about the simple, apparently incidental life choices we make every day,
than some gallant grand gesture we might make in the face of some crisis
or calamity.

Laying down your life is to see every day as an opportunity to serve
and encourage others.

I think if we make it into some kind of super heroic act, it robs us
of the honour of exercising everyday mundane servant-hood.

The only way we can avoid laying down our lives is to resist the
purposes of God and live outside his will.

Laying down your life will look very different for different people,
and how it looks in practical terms is up to every individual to work
out. A guiding principle in working the practical implications of living
a 'Laid down life,' is that your paramount concern is the welfare and
needs of others.

How do we lay down our lives?

As we unpack this passage we will discover that we will never lay down
our lives if we are motivated with shame or guilt. Nor will we be able
to lay down our lives simply by determination or effort; rather the life
that is laid down for the sake of others is first and foremost an
expression of character. Laying down our lives for others is more about
an expression of our natures than it is about responding to the needs of
others. Jesus gives four reasons why he lay down his life for the sheep.
It is more about the people we are than the spiritual gifts we may
have.

\[a\] The Good shepherd lays down his life because He is good.

'I am the good shepherd, and the good shepherd lays down his life for
the sheep.' The word good (Greek: kalos) shepherd. Barclay notes that
there are two Greek words for good. The first is agathos, which \"simply
describes the moral quality of a thing.\" The second is kalos, \"which
means that a thing or a person is not only good; but in the goodness
there is a quality of winsomeness, loveliness, attractiveness which
makes it a lovely thing.\" It refers to someone who was more than just a
good person.
[https://www.trinitycoatesville.org/sermons/whats-good-about-a-shepherd-2](https://www.trinitycoatesville.org/sermons/whats-good-about-a-shepherd-2)
(Accessed 10/04/25)

They would also be someone that we could count on to be there for us
in a time of crisis. Someone who would offer us support, prays for us,
or brings meals by for us. They would be the person that we could call
in the middle of the night without reservation if we needed them.

In Classical literature the word kalos was a picture word that was
used to describe

A Suitable Harbour.

A Healthy Body.

Pure genuine gold.

An unblemished sacrifice.

\[b\] The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep because of
the relationship he has with them.

'I am the good shepherd; I know my sheep and my sheep know me- Just as
the Father knows me and I know the Father- and I lay down my life for
the sheep.'

I think this is one of the most profound verses in the New
Testament.,,

Jesus models his relationships with people on his relationship with
his father, 'I know my sheep and my sheep know me- Just as the Father
knows me and I know the father.' The implications of these words are
very scary. If we were to have the same kind of relationships with
people that we have with God, what kind of community would we be? The
heart attitudes that a person needs to know and love God, are the same
heart attitudes we need to know and love people.

We cannot say that we love God and hate our brother. The only way we
can lay down our lives for God is to lay it down for people

Because Jesus knew his sheep he laid down his life. It is easier to
live a sacrificial life in order to help a friend than it is to help a
stranger.

Many people in positions of leadership struggle with fulfilling their
God given responsibilities because they are emotionally disengaged from
those they are trying to serve and lead. Knowing the sheep will help the
shepherd to lay down his life. If you understand and care for the people
God has made you responsible for, you are going to want to lay down your
life in order to show your love for them.
prayer:
Father, give me the desire so I can lay down my life for
those you have given me to care for.
